Pre-Game Insights: India would be keen not to repeat the mistakes of the 2022 T20 World Cup semi-final against England
India are looking the favourites as they cruised into the semi-finals, winning all the six matches they played so far
England were beaten by Australia as they barely managed to squeeze into the Super 8s stage on the net run rate but seem to have regained their mojo
India have struggled in the big knockout games in ICC events in the last decade
Last year, they lost to Australia in the World Test Championship final and the ODI World Cup final, while a year before they were beaten by England in the semi-finals of the T20 World Cup in 2022
In T20 World Cups, India have choked in big games including the 2014 T20 World Cup final against Sri Lanka and the 2016 T20 World Cup semi-finals against the West Indies
In ODI World Cups too, India have succumbed under the pressure of knockout games, losing to Australia and New Zealand in the semi-finals of the 2015 and 2019 World Cups respectively
Miscellaneous Highlights: This year, India are looking the favourites as they cruised into the semi-finals, winning all the six matches they played so far
India have struggled in the big knockout games in ICC events in the last decade
Last year, they lost to Australia in the World Test Championship final and the ODI World Cup final, while a year before they were beaten by England in the semi-finals of the T20 World Cup in 2022
In T20 World Cups, India have choked in big games including the 2014 T20 World Cup final against Sri Lanka and the 2016 T20 World Cup semi-finals against the West Indies
In ODI World Cups too, India have succumbed under the pressure of knockout games, losing to Australia and New Zealand in the semi-finals of the 2015 and 2019 World Cups respectively
Others: The Indian spin trio of Kuldeep, Jadeja and Axar Patel will have their task cut against the trio of Jonny Bairstow, Moeen Ali and Harry Brook, who like to bat aggressively against spin in the middle overs
England's most dangerous batter in the death overs is Liam Livingstone, who boasts of a strike rate of 151 in T20 Internationals. If he gets going he could make a big difference in the last few overs
all-rounder Sam Curran at No. 7 is also quite handy with the bat
